cMewqjNCKh8rVb-mXv4Wpw.text: Remember the days of wasabi tei in far east plaza? The nasty hot tempered owner has become much nicer towards his customers in this new store. The store is very extensive and serves fresh sushi.If you are going for economical, you can try the 10$++ set menu which is good enough for one person. Definitely if you would like to indulge, the chirashi set/don would be most appropriate to satisfy you.I must say the sashimi is well prepared, the freshness is there, the sweetness of fish and it is served in thick slab, not skimpy. Remember to make reservation in advance as it is almost impossible to get a seat as they have some time slot system .

RkZaIcUklqmuJch5tJbQmQ.text: You need to book in advance for this place. They have a strange duo shift system, where you need to choose between two time slots when you book, 630 to Very good Chirashi don. Very generous with their servings of fish, Huge slabs of salmon, tuna, and other fish. Very fresh and succulent. The sweetness of the fish really comes through. . Their Chawanmushi is also something special. I usually do not really like chawanmushi bit over here, it's full of chunks of chicken, prawns, and mushrooms. If you are not into raw fish, the other sets are also generally very good. The nabe teishoku (codfish and vegetables in claypot) come highly recommended.

m9b_KFmCLOht-6AGi5viMg.text: Very good price to quality ratio.  Thick cut sushi at affordable prices.  The hot dishes are also quite tasty.  The egg dish (chawanmushi) and terriyaki cod I have found to be particularly good.  Staff are friendly.  It is not your "authentic" Japanese place, but again, you're not paying for it either.

n-KO86p4Hoe52tl9rAygQQ.text: So you're likely spoiled for choice for decent Japanese in Singapore where the Japanese dining experience is represented all the way from the likes of Shinji (now closed to my absolute regret), to fast food and ramen bars.  Chikuwa Tei is somewhere in between. It's a very solidly mid-upper range Japanese bistro whose menu includes a very decent selection of good quality chiraishi don and sashimi-based entrees.   The outlet here has a sushi bar and a dining area with tops.I'm no expert, but I do like what I like and what this joint puts out is pretty solid stuff. Definitely hard to fault and for that price point, pretty solid on value too.   The fish is fresh, pleasant on the palate, clean to the eye and for me, continues to feel good long after dinner.  This last is particularly important, as not everything positive gustatory experience at the table lasts.  Too often the umami that keeps you coming back for mouthfuls and makes for oohs and aahs at the table is the product of the same monosodium glutamate that hours later comes back to smite you with dry mouth, a mild headache and an unquenchable thirst.  The dining experience at Chikuwa Tei, the one time that I've dined in and the few times that I've gotten take out has been consistent with the flavor of fresh ingredients being forward and allowed to represent themselves without too much gussying up. Overall, one of those solid, consistent Japanese joints that are unlikely to compromise on quality to keep the price point stable.  At least not till now and I'm keeping my fingers crossed...

photos.caption: Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Bright Long dining room with light wood decor!  Sets the mood just right for the cuisine!

Stf5NOV42NtoGDZNG50Lvw.text: My first meal here was delicious, the chirashi set was perfect, as were the sides. On a recent lunch visit however, I was disappointed as the sashimi was too cold, as if it had just been thawed, and tasted less than fresh. Our yellowtail collar was also over cooked. The service was pleasant enough, but given how empty the restaurant was, I would have expected it to be a little more attentive.

FRxoSEf2YOfYX29IBLruqA.text: Drop by since this is near my yoga place. If I can give it negative star, I would. Sorry, I won't be coming back. The only decent thing is the Sapporo beer. Don't even try the wine by the glass.. it's like 50% of a standard glass.

ZpR_LqzQUSNCCh_5cxeCRg.text: Finally had lunch here to try the famed chirashi don. It was a disappointment. I was seated at the counter, and it smells. Of pee, of not properly washed tops of fish, of damp cloth. And then the food: I had the chirashi kou, the more expensive chirashi option. With two cubes of soft watermelon and a miso soup, the chirashi bowl was small, and not very generous slices of fish (just two of each): salmon, maguro, scallops sandwiches tightly between lemon slices to mask its staleness, hamachi that was fishy, two sweet shrimp and unagi. Some ikura. The fish was mediocre. The rice was passable but some bits clumpy. And not sufficiently filling. Would never return. Sooner head to sushi bar for a decent bowl of chirashi.Edit: and they charge $0.60 for a glass of water!! They didn't even inform me of that! Disgusting.

K0L1Yc3omwfQgredZm6P0Q.text: This place came highly recommended for the chirashi, which was pretty good but not best.  However, if you enjoy a glass of wine as I do, do not order here!  I saw a 1-for-1 deal at $18, red or white.  We received 2 glasses of maybe 2 sips each, and it was very mediocre stuff.  When I inquired about the short pour, the auntie said "2 ounces" and promptly walked away.  So much for 1-for-1, we didn't even get 1!  As I paid the bill, totally appauled at having just paid $18 for 4 ounces of cheap wine, I mentioned that a standard wine pour is 5 ounces.  She said cheerfully "okay!  Bye bye".  Left a bitter taste in my mouth (no pun intended) and I shall not return.  At the least they should indicate the non-standard pour size on the menu!!

ZzfbmSZFFxlpbCY8nCaUxQ.text: I applaud you, Chikuwa Tei.1. For having really pretty red menus that so prettily lay out exactly what each lunch set will include.2. For having BIG portion sizes. I can't remember the last time I said that about a Japanese restaurant (maybe because it never happened??)Seriously though. I totally could've shared my lunch set and been happy. Heaping plate of fried udon noodles, 5 chunky slices of salmon, miso soup, watermelon - all for $14. Most sets are $15-$20; chirashi starts at $25. Everything was flavored well and delicious.I imagine 2 sets could very comfortably feed 3 people, so share away! Super pleasant atmosphere and service. It's a splurgey kind of lunch, but great ROI ;)

0Vr_58CZCNTHf_dzun3alw.text: It's no secret to anyone that knows me that Chikuwa Tei and me go well together like THISSSSSSSS. *Gestures Hand SHOWING "WE TIGHT LIKE THAT"Whenever the sashimi craving comes, this place IMMEDIATELY comes to mind.You just can't beat the prices here for the thickness of slices of fish you get with the Chirashi Bowl! They also have a premium chirashi bowl and will try definitely try to sell you that, but that one costs 3x the price! I normally only go for the normal one and tell them I only want Salmon, Salmon Belly and Swordfish - my all time favourites when it comes to sashimi. Their rice is so tasty but could be a little bit more. I can't complain coz of the price though. What issit like...$25bucks per bowl? I like their Botan Ibi sashimi too, however it isn't for everyone. What they normally do is make soup out of their heads for you so as not to waste it. And if i'm feeling a bit more generous... I'll order the Steak Fois Gras! OMG. It will BLOW YOUR MIND.Service is friendly... other things on the menu can be a bit pricey like other high end jap places. But of course everywhere is the same - you pay for quality. But if you stick to the items I mentioned, it shouldnt cost more than 60-70 per head eating quality +Quantity items which are bang for buck!Currently, there are many Chirashi Bowl compettion out there but till this day, this place is MOST DEFINITELY the bench mark on terms of quality, quantity and pricing!!P.S -  Don't be shy to ask for the normal Chirashi Set if you're not so set on splurging on the premium set and feel free to tell them which types of sashimi exactly u only want! :) Salmon Belly is amazingggggg in my books! Oh and one more extremely important point - BETTER make sure to make reservations if you're having dinner there. Lunch seems to be fine though. Don't say I didn't warn you!

photos.caption: Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Soft Shell Crab
Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Steak Foie Gras
Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Chirashi Don

j4gJCXN599A8tBJRWZoaXw.text: I would return JUST for their sashimi bowl! For $25, you enjoy generous thick slices of fresh fish!! Beautiful!I also read for others that you can customise your own sashimi bowl. As I only enjoy salmon and swordfish, I asked only for those!I must not forget to sing praises for the side dishes too! I love their grilled pork skin and grilled mentai cod fish and their sushi plates. All wonderful and tasty! The shop front is one that you may miss if you are not looking out for it. I'm glad I found it and had such a wonderful dinner!

8nAV_N7CDcrKC6YAtBejKw.text: One of my favorite Japanese restaurant has got to be Chikuwa Tei, which is located at Mohamed Sultan Road near Robertson Quay. I have been frequenting this restaurant for at least 2 years and it has always provided good food at reasonable prices.There are 18 bento sets to choose from, from S$12 to $25, the most expensive being the Chirashi set. I've tried a couple of their bentos and the quality is pretty consistent.If you like Sashimi, you would love this. Just look at the generous chunks of fresh fish piled on top of the vinegar rice! Each piece is about 10cm long and at least 1cm thick and you can taste the fresh sweetness of the fish. S orders this everytime we go there.Depending on my mood, i would go for Ten Cha Soba set ($12) when i want something lighter. Or their Chikuwa Tei set when i'm really greedy. They have 2 sets, 1 for individual and another for 2pax. It is more pricy (about S$40-50/pax) but there is a variety of dishes, from grilled to tempura and sukiyaki even.Anyway, i love the refreshing cha soba which has a tinge of matcha taste in it (not all cha soba tastes of green tea). The texture of the green noodles is also very spingy and the dipping sauce is of the right amount of saltiness. The California maki (S$8) is also very satisfying. In fact, it's quite a huge portion. The chef is very generous with the avocado and flying fish roe. There is no need for soy sauce because the natural saltiness of the roe is sufficient for flavoring. If you were wondering if it's the same notorious chef from Wasabi Tei at Far East Square, it is (or was). I didn't see him the last time i was there so i'm not sure if they have changed their chef.

photos.caption: Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. cha soba
Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. california maki
Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. chirashidon

wZF1X822_FgoIBJSAH9irA.text: Dined at this place near my office on a Tuesday night and at around 6.30pm, the place was still quite empty although it filled up pretty nicely at around 7.15pm.The salmon sashimi cannot beat Wasabi Tei's thick and generous serving. At twice the price of Wasabi Tei's, I must say this barely comes close with the salmon having a slight fishy smell.The ebi maki comes in at the number 2 spot after Wasabi Tei's. Not enough crunch, less prawn and smaller in size, well there you go.Not a bad place to dine in but for better quality sashimi that doesn't break the bank, I still prefer Wasabi Tei.

photos.caption: Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Yaki udon nabe
Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Deep fried prawn maki
Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Salmon sashimi

K3k6ATYTh7EGvpGpsFwfJA.text: I see what the hype is about now. Succulent and thick cuts of fish arranged to form a bed for pearls of ikura. That said, we were ushered in and hustled to our seats seconds after stepping into the restaurant. After packing our food away, the wait staff cleared our plates out even before my chawanmushi was served. So yes, customer service was pretty hurried but well... For the price & quality of food we get? I wouldn't complain.

photos.caption: Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Chirashi Don

3coevSfc4PhSVrzXNdDQ7A.text: Ordered the wagyu beef and onsen egg, looks different from the picture, beef was so rubbery and tasteless.  I left half of the beef, don't know what I was eating. I definitely won't be back. I would give it negative if I could.

qhmcIfCfjO_Jw_yPeA5e3Q.text: Based on my first visit (consistency is not part of the review):Proper sushi, looks for daily special because some of the fishes are important from Japan directly.Decent list of food menu, comparable to Japan izakaya.My favorite here is kurobuta yaki!Drink menu is too little.average service against Japanese standard.

photos.caption: Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore. Sushi morisawase

QqRunYgUrYm1n30l5vHPhg.text: This is a ZERO star review; hardly close to a one star. The reason for this is due to the horrendous reservation service. We made a reservation a week in advance and reported 15 minutes earlier than our reservation time. There was a long queue when we arrived and we were patient enough to wait outside. However, after 8 and still waiting, we were passed over by groups whom Esmond, the young partner, claimed that they have been waiting for a good time before us. We were understanding about the long wait until he gave our table to a group of Caucasians who walked in a good 45 minutes after us!! We confronted him about his rationale behind this gesture and he claimed that they booked their table a month before and reserved tables for 830. We reserved our table for 8pm and a week early. It is complete bollocks!!! Why should an 8.30pm reservation be seated before an 8pm reservation?!? He proceeded to claim this was a "real time real world" problem. I can't see any other problem other than his poor service management skills. Clearly he has a post colonial hang up - choosing to serve a group of non-locals over a group of locals; and a mercenary streak for allowing a group which made a reservation for 5 but showed up for 10 be seated prior to other reservation bookings.

53bwQjvJ0jbOMxVMnxQ4TQ.text: Simple, casual and fuss free, Chikuwa Tei is one of my favourite 'easy' dinners to go when I crave Japanese food. With over 18 bento sets to choose from that are available at very affordable prices, I'm almost spoilt for choice each time I visit. One of their most expensive sets has to be the Chirashi set, which is also one of my favourites. If you enjoy sashimi, you'll love the Chirashi set. What it basically is just huge chunks of fresh fish piled on top of the rice. Being great value for money, you can taste the freshness and sweetness of each fish as you take a bite.

photos.caption: Photo of Chikuwa Tei - Singapore, Singapore

VoXRoQiKkPxJXNeEG0lHNg.text: If you're looking for an average quality Japanese meal in the Robertson Quay area, Chikuwa Tei might be your best bet. My friend brought me here, and it seems like everyone orders the Chirashi. I was sitting at the sushi bar and the chef seemed to be banging out bowl after bowl of Chirashi.All the staff were local, and they provided great service. I would say that this was probably the most value for money meal I had all week. Protip: Make a reservations so you don't have to wait.

vvqEMvAxl3gTeIxyWr1R7Q.text: This is my favourite place for Chirashi don because they are very generous with the sashimi slices. Sake selection is pretty good too.It's definitely a good place for dinner. Do make reservations on weekends as there's always a queue.I'm going there tonight!

b4trM1TiWkYxwEiIz05E2g.text: This is currently our favorite casual dining sushi joint.  We've been probably about a dozen times.  It's not as crowded, full of expats, expensive or pretentious as many of the the other places on Mohammed Sultan.  The menu is pretty extensive, and the kids can get teriyaki salmon or chicken dinners or udon while I can get sashimi.  If you have a slightly larger group (say around 8+), you can use the private room in the back.  Generally, I like this place.Caveat emptor - do not commit the folly that my husband and I recently did (unless you are a belly tuna afficionado) - blithely nodding when the sushi chef offered us the belly tuna "just in from Japan."  We were perfectly content with regular maguro and are game to try anything new, but we in fact found the belly tuna too chewy and gamey for our tastes.  The shocker on the bill was that the four petite slabs set us back by $50.Still looking for that clutch sushi place here in Singapore...

nrqKXWsujypXlo53gvDoRw.text: Went on a lunch date with a girl friend. I've been craving sashimi for a few days and was looking forward to the array of options on the Chirashi-bowl. I've tried the restaurant on few other occasions and was happy with the quality of the fish for the rather moderate price. However, I was disappointed with the lunch. It was too obvious that some of the fish had been frozen and tasted a bit like a supermarket's grab-and-go bento box sushi. Three-stars because of its solid record from the past. Hopefully, this was just a one-off incident.

iORhImQlIjHUV3bvM1rqTQ.text: I tried this restaurant on Sunday for lunch. The place is quite small and simple.  Service is ok. We ordered a Chirashi (25sgd) and a cod fish set (20 sgd).The Sashimi was very fresh and of unexpected generous portions (plus it was ready after just 5 minutes). The cod fish came together with a small salad and was well cooked and tasty.  Both sets included a miso soup and two slices of watermelon. Overall, a good place for sushi/sashimi with reasonable price.
